FAQ: How Do I Know if My Child Needs Speech Therapy?

Kim Christensen, Early Childhood Professional + Parent

Ages
2-3,
3-4
Social + Emotional
Language + Literacy

We’re often asked, “How do I know if my child needs speech therapy?” First, listen to your instincts. If you feel something is off with your child’s communication development or behavior, it’s usually for a reason. Second, ask yourself this set of questions. If you answer “Yes” to any of these questions, you should seek an evaluation with a speech-language pathologist. Don’t be shy. Delay can sometimes come at a developmental cost

*Note – Suggestions in this article do not replace individualized professional intervention specific to your child’s needs. Some services may be offered through public agencies. Be sure to consult your local resources.

Do

Questions You Should Ask Yourself

(PRINT ME!)

Question What You Could Do
  • Is my child’s speech hard to understand?
  • Speech errors are expected throughout early child development and the nature and quantity of those errors can be typical or atypical. For example, you may notice patterns such as sounds being left off the end of words (“bu” for “bus”) or missing syllables (“e-phant” for “elephant”), which may or may not be concerning depending on your child’s age and stage.
  • A speech-language pathologist can educate you about what is normal or expected at each stage and make a recommendation for the best plan of action (which may even be to “wait and see”).
  • Is my child having a hard time communicating or connecting with others?
  • Even at a young age, children should be interactive with others. Babies can carry on wordless “conversations” through facial expressions, noises and gestures. As children grow, these skills evolve into more sophisticated communication skills.
  • If, at any stage, you notice your child is having a hard time connecting (playing or interacting with others) or communicating (understanding others, expressing him/herself), seek an evaluation.
  • Is my child frustrated and acting out because they can’t communicate well?
  • Frustration and communication challenges often go hand-in-hand.
  • Despite the many online resources on this topic, without a comprehensive in-person assessment, it’s hard to know what is typical behavior and what may be related to a speech, language or other delay.
  • Does my child seem behind their peers or siblings?
  • While it is often advised not to compare your child to their peers or siblings (all children develop at their own pace), it can be helpful to become familiar with what children are doing, generally, at your child’s age and stage.
  • Your most accessible resource will be your child’s peers at school or in your neighborhood. Check-in with your child’s teacher to get their perspective. Or learn more about communication milestones. If you are noticing significant differences in your child’s communication, behavior or social skills, it may be worth seeking an evaluation.
  • Has anyone else (teacher, doctor, friend, relative, child’s peer) commented or inquired about my child’s communication skills?
  • It is true that in a home environment we can sometimes grow accustomed to how a child miscommunicates.
  • Sometimes other people who know your child will pick up on challenges or differences that you don’t notice in your home environment or during your normal routine.
  • If you notice others – adults or children – frequently asking you to translate what your child said, it may be an indicator that your child needs some speech support.
  • Has my pediatrician suggested speech therapy?
  • No. And that’s OK. It’s ultimately up to you to seek a speech evaluation for your child, regardless of your pediatrician’s opinion.
  • System-wise, if you plan to use your health insurance to fund the evaluation, you may need a pediatrician’s referral. Consider getting a second opinion from another pediatrician if you’re having difficulty getting a referral from your pediatrician and are concerned about your child. Alternatively, you may consider pursuing an evaluation outside of your health plan.

 

Next Steps

If you answered “Yes” to any of the above questions and determined you would like to consult with an expert, here are your next steps:

  • Find a speech-language pathologist. This is the only type of professional that can diagnose your child with a speech or language disorder and provide the necessary treatment.
    • Every speech-language pathologist holds at least a Master’s degree and specializes in speech and language disorders.
  • If your child does need speech support, budget extra time and attention to help them practice.
    • Like all things, practice makes better. “Practice” will look different at each child’s age and stage. For example, “practice” may simply mean modifying the way you do a routine activity (such as encouraging your child to ask for “milk” using a word instead of a grunt) or may be something you need to sit down and do for a couple of minutes per day, like running through a set of speech cards to practice a specific sound.
    • Frequent, short practices are most effective, so the time commitment to practice should be manageable and sustainable. Try to prioritize this in a fun, playful way.

Share Favorite Print

Are you hearing sound patterns that are concerning? Tell us.

Kim Christensen, Early Childhood Professional + Parent

Kim is a speech-language pathologist with her own practice at SF Speech for Kids. She has worked with children and adults for more than 15 years, and has advanced training in autism spectrum disorders, apraxia of speech and nonverbal children. Kim frequently consults with the Autism Center of Northern California and JumpStart Learning to Learn. Kim graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, with a degree in sociology, and has a Master of Science in Communicative Disorders from San Francisco State University. Above all, Kim is a proud mother and founder of SF Smiles.
